standard_metadata.standard_description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

question.content: **Plot the image of point $A$ under a reflection across line $\ell$.**

hints.content: A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.    [[☃ image 1]]  In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

images.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content: Point $A$ is $4$ units directly to the right of line $\ell$, so $A'$ will be $4$ units to the left of the line and have the same $y$-coordinate as $A$.
This is the image of point $A$:      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Point A is reflected across vertical line l. The new point and point A are both four units from line l.

question.content: Point $Q'$ is the image of $Q(3, -4)$ under a reflection across the $x$-axis.  **What are the coordinates of $Q'$?**  $($  $,$  $)$

hints.content: A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.    [[☃ image 1]]  In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

images.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content: We want to reflect $Q(3,-4)$ across the $x$-axis.      [[☃ image 1]]  Point $Q$ is $4$ units directly below the $x$-axis, so $Q'$ will be $4$ units above the axis and have the same $x$-coordinate as $Q$.  Algebraically, this means a reflection across the $x$-axis is the transformation $(x,y) \to (x,-y)$.

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point Q is at three, negative four.

hints.content: $\begin{align} Q &\to Q' \\\\ (x,y) &\to (x,-y) \\\\ (3, -4) &\to (3,-(-4)) \end{align}$
**The coordinates of $Q'$ are $(3, 4)$.**  This is how it looks graphically:    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point Q is at three, negative four. The point is reflected across the x-axis to form a new point at three, four labeled Q prime. Both points are four units from the x axis.

question.content: Point $D'$ is the image of $D(-2, 1)$ under a reflection across the $x$-axis.  **What are the coordinates of $D'$?**  $($  $,$  $)$

hints.content: We want to reflect $D(-2, 1)$ across the $x$-axis.      [[☃ image 1]]  Point $D$ is $1$ units directly above the $x$-axis, so $D'$ will be $1$ units below the axis and have the same $x$-coordinate as $D$.  Algebraically, this means a reflection across the $x$-axis is the transformation $(x,y) \to (x,-y)$.

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point D is at negative two, one.

hints.content: A reflection moves a point perpendicularly across a line, so that the [[☃ definition 1]] is the same distance from the line as the [[☃ definition 2]], but on the other side.    [[☃ image 1]]  In other words, the line of reflection is the perpendicular bisector between any pair of corresponding points in the image and the pre-image.

images.alt: Point R is reflected across a line to form point R prime. Segment R R prime is perpendicular to the line.

hints.content: $\begin{align} D &\to D' \\\\ (x,y) &\to (x,-y) \\\\ (-2, 1) &\to (-2,-(1)) \end{align}$
**The coordinates of $D'$ are $(-2, -1)$.**  This is how it looks graphically:      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point D is at negative two, one. The point is reflected across the x-axis to form a new point at negative two, negative one. Both points are one unit from the x axis.

question.content: Point $C'$ is the image of $C(-4, -2)$ under a reflection across the $y$-axis.  **What are the coordinates of $C'$?**  $($  $,$  $)$

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point C is at negative four, negative two.

hints.content: **The coordinates of $C'$ are $(4, -2)$.**  This is how it looks graphically:      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Point C is at negative four, negative two. The point is reflected across the y-axis to form a new point at four, negative two. Both points are four units from the y axis.
